Title: Lost & Found, Part 1
Summary: On the harsh mining world of Tars Lamora, a wisecracking teen named Dal R'El dreams of escape but is kept in line by shock collars, language barriers, and the terrifying enforcer Drednok, who serves the mysterious overlord known only as the Diviner. Dal’s failed attempt to flee brands him a troublemaker, yet it also brings him into contact with a hulking young miner called Rok-Tahk and the enigmatic Medusan Zero, a non-corporeal being who has already escaped the Diviner once and now manipulates its containment suit to help others. When Dal is sent to search the deep caverns for a rumored "Unwanted" prisoner, he instead discovers the buried Starfleet starship USS Protostar, and realizes that the key to freedom may not be a tunnel out of the colony but a ship that can take them far beyond it.

StorySections.Text: Dal R'El scrambles across the jagged surface of Tars Lamora in a frantic, improvised escape attempt, only to be captured by drones and dragged back to the mine as the Diviner’s forces demonstrate how tightly they control every prisoner on the asteroid.

Returned to the grinding routines of the prison colony, Dal is interrogated by Drednok about a supposed "Fugitive" no one can identify because the miners have no universal translators. Dal bluffs his way through the encounter, holding onto his sense of humor even as the threat of punishment hangs over him.

Assigned to work alongside the shy, heavily-armored Rok-Tahk, Dal witnesses how isolated every prisoner is without a shared language and how ruthlessly the Diviner’s regime exploits that isolation. Meanwhile, the unseen Zero subtly interferes with equipment and guards, quietly laying the groundwork for a larger escape.

Dal is forced to accompany a mining rig into the deep caverns to search for a rumored dangerous "Unwanted". During the expedition, sabotage and shifting rock reveal a long-buried, intact starship: the USS Protostar. Dal sneaks aboard, marveling at unfamiliar Starfleet technology and glimpsing the possibility of a life beyond Tars Lamora.

As the Diviner and Drednok grow impatient for results, Dal races to keep the ship a secret while plotting how to use it as an escape route. Rok-Tahk and the ever-mischievous Murf are drawn into his scheme, and Zero reveals themself as an ally, proposing that together they could steal the Protostar right out from under the Diviner’s nose.

Back in his chambers, the Diviner insists that the mysterious ship hidden beneath his own prison must be found at any cost, even as Dal and his new companions begin to imagine what it might mean to leave the asteroid forever.

EntitySummaries.Dal R'El: Dal R'El is the impulsive, big-hearted leader of the Protostar crew, a former prisoner who seizes his first real chance at freedom. Across these episodes he grows from a reckless runaway into a young officer learning how to put his crew and the wider galaxy ahead of his own ego.
EntitySummaries.Drednok: Drednok is a relentless robotic enforcer who serves as one of the most direct physical threats to the Protostar crew. His presence turns many encounters into life-or-death confrontations and represents the cold, unforgiving machinery behind the villains' plans.
EntitySummaries.Gwyndala: Gwyndala is a Vau N'Akat raised as a weapon who chooses a different path, fighting to repair the damage her people and her father helped cause. Her journey in these stories centers on balancing loyalty to Solum with her responsibility to the friends and ideals she found aboard the Protostar.
EntitySummaries.Jankom Pog: Jankom Pog is a Tellarite engineer who complains loudly but always shows up when the ship—and his friends—need him most. His gruff exterior hides real ingenuity and heart, and his mechanical skill often makes the difference between disaster and a daring escape.
EntitySummaries.Murf: Murf is the seemingly indestructible, ever-hungry member of the crew whose true capabilities reveal themselves slowly over time. What begins as a comedic mascot becomes a surprising source of resilience, insight, and even guidance as the temporal stakes grow higher.
EntitySummaries.Rok-Tahk: Rok-Tahk is the gentle giant of the crew, a brilliant young scientist and engineer who once thought of herself only as muscle. Throughout the season she uses her curiosity and patience to solve problems no one else can, proving that kindness and careful thinking are real superpowers.

EntitySummaries.The Diviner: The Diviner plays a complicated, sometimes adversarial role in the events around the Protostar and Voyager-A. They challenge the young crew in ways that raise the stakes and force harder choices.
EntitySummaries.Zero: Zero is a Medusan whose unshielded form can harm others, forcing them to live behind a containment suit even as they become the crew's navigator and conscience. Their arc in these episodes explores identity, connection, and the challenge of being profoundly different while still craving closeness and trust.

ContinuityNotes: Introduces the Delta Quadrant mining colony of Tars Lamora as the primary setting for the early Prodigy arc.
First appearance of Dal R'El, Rok-Tahk, Zero, Jankom Pog, Murf, the Diviner, and Drednok.
Hints at Starfleet and the Federation only as distant rumors, setting up the reveal of the Protostar as the crew’s first real contact with Starfleet technology.
ThematicNotes: Explores isolation and communication barriers by denying the prisoners universal translators, emphasizing how language can be used as a tool of control.
Begins a coming-of-age story about marginalized kids discovering they can choose their own future.
Contrasts despair and hope as Dal’s reckless optimism turns a hopeless prison sentence into the first step toward freedom.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as the first half of Prodigy’s two-part pilot, introducing the core cast and the Tars Lamora setting.
The visual design of Tars Lamora emphasizes brutal industrial machinery contrasted with the sleek, hidden Starfleet lines of the Protostar.
The episode establishes Prodigy’s approach of explaining Star Trek concepts—like Starfleet and the Federation—from the perspective of characters who have never heard of them.

Title: Lost & Found, Part 2
Summary: Dal’s discovery of the USS Protostar turns into a full-scale prison break, as he recruits Rok-Tahk, Zero, Jankom Pog, and even the talkative blob Murf into helping him steal the starship out from under the Diviner’s watchful eye. When the Diviner’s daughter Gwyn is sent to interrogate Dal and recover the "Fugitive," she instead becomes entangled in his plan and learns how much her father has withheld from her about the miners and their treatment. The escape spirals into a chaotic chase as drones and Drednok converge on the buried ship, but Dal’s impulsive leap to power up the Protostar succeeds: the young crew blasts free of the asteroid, only to find themselves confronted by a holographic training program in the form of Captain Kathryn Janeway, who calmly asks what Starfleet mission they intend to undertake.

StorySections.Text: In the wake of the Protostar’s discovery, Dal scrambles to keep its existence secret while trying to figure out how to operate the ship, narrowly avoiding detection by patrol drones in the caverns.

Dal recruits Rok-Tahk, Zero, and Murf to help with his plan, luring the skeptical Tellarite Jankom Pog aboard with the promise of food and freedom. The group stumbles through Starfleet technology, activating systems they barely understand as they search for a way to take off.

The Diviner orders Gwyn to locate the rumored ship and the "Fugitive" meddling in his plans. Gwyn tracks Dal, interrogates him, and begins to suspect that her father is hiding the true nature of the miners’ exploitation. Meanwhile, Drednok sends a swarm of drones into the caverns to secure the Protostar.

Dal and his ragtag crew improvise a desperate launch as drones breach the Protostar’s hull and Drednok personally descends to stop them. In the chaos, Gwyn attempts to seize control but is left behind on the surface while Dal uses the ship’s thrusters to blast out of the asteroid’s crust, leaving Tars Lamora in their wake—for the moment.

Once clear of the asteroid, the fledgling crew marvels at open space and argues over where to go, only for the ship to suddenly activate a holographic Emergency Training Hologram based on Kathryn Janeway. Janeway immediately begins instructing them in Starfleet basics, assuming they are cadets in need of guidance.

Back on Tars Lamora, the Diviner vows to pursue the Protostar and retrieve his starship at any cost, while Gwyn, stranded among the rubble, realizes that both her loyalty and her future have been thrown into doubt.

ThematicNotes: Examines chosen family as the kids begin to shift from isolated survivors to a nascent crew.
Challenges inherited loyalty when Gwyn realizes her father’s version of events doesn’t match what she sees.
Highlights the gap between Starfleet ideals and the lawless margins of the galaxy where those ideals are only rumors.
BehindTheScenes: Completes the series’ two-part premiere story, fully assembling the Protostar crew.
Features the first extended appearance of the Janeway hologram, voiced by Kate Mulgrew, tying Prodigy directly to Star Trek: Voyager.
The two-part pilot was designed as a single continuous story, introducing core characters before fully engaging with broader Star Trek lore.

Title: Starstruck
Summary: With the Protostar finally free, Hologram Janeway enthusiastically offers to brief the young crew on Starfleet, the Federation, and the basics of running a starship. Dal, desperate to prove himself as captain, repeatedly ignores her advice, treating Janeway as an optional tutorial rather than a seasoned mentor. His reckless decision to take a flashy shortcut through a dangerous stellar phenomenon nearly destroys the ship and strands them in a collapsing gravity well. Only by swallowing his pride, accepting Janeway’s help, and listening to his crewmates does Dal manage to steer the Protostar to safety, nudging the team one step closer to becoming a real Starfleet-style crew.

StorySections.Text: A wide-eyed Dal tours the Protostar’s bridge as Hologram Janeway delivers a rousing overview of the Federation and Starfleet, complete with holographic star charts and historical highlights that utterly fail to impress his jaded crew.

Janeway proposes a sensible course toward Federation space, but Dal insists on asserting his authority, declaring himself captain and vetoing her recommendations. He orders the ship toward a visually impressive but poorly understood binary system, turning off safety protocols and ignoring warnings.

As the Protostar enters the hazardous region, gravitational forces begin to tear at the hull and disable systems. Rok, Zero, and Jankom scramble to keep the ship together while Dal doubles down on his decisions, unwilling to admit he is in over his head. Janeway’s calm suggestions grow more urgent as conditions worsen.

The situation becomes critical when the ship is dragged toward a crushing gravity well. Confronted with disaster and his crew’s fear, Dal finally concedes that he needs help and allows Janeway to resume control of navigation and emergency procedures. Working together, the crew executes a precise escape burn that barely clears the danger zone.

Safely back in normal space, Dal begrudgingly acknowledges that Janeway might know a thing or two about command, and the crew agrees to give Starfleet-style teamwork a real chance. Janeway, for her part, adjusts her approach to treat them less like cadets and more like traumatized kids learning to trust again.

Far away, the Diviner continues tracking faint signatures from the Protostar, convinced that his stolen ship and its young crew will eventually lead him to the future he believes was stolen from his people.

ContinuityNotes: Provides the crew’s first in-universe primer on the United Federation of Planets and Starfleet.
References Starfleet protocols and chain of command, laying groundwork for later discussions of regulations and ethics.
Shows that the Protostar is equipped with advanced navigation and safety systems comparable to late-24th-century Federation starships.
ThematicNotes: Explores the difference between wanting authority and earning leadership through responsibility and humility.
Highlights the value of mentorship, as Janeway adapts to the needs of a crew that distrusts all authority figures.
Reinforces the central idea that Starfleet’s strength comes from collaboration and listening, not individual bravado.
BehindTheScenes: Acts as the first "day-in-the-life" episode aboard the Protostar, focusing on shipboard dynamics over prison-escape action.
Gives Hologram Janeway extended exposition about the Federation, effectively onboarding new viewers to Star Trek concepts.
The episode’s hazards visually showcase the Protostar’s effects-heavy animation and dynamic starship maneuvering.

Title: Dream Catcher
Summary: Eager to fulfill what they think a Starfleet mission should look like, the Protostar crew lands on a lush, uncharted planet that appears to offer each of them exactly what they want most—fields of adorable animals for Rok, tools and food for Jankom, answers and belonging for Dal, and scientific wonders for Zero. Janeway warns them to stay cautious and work as a team, but the planet’s environment subtly isolates each crewmember in a personalized illusion, luring them farther from the ship. When the crew realizes the world itself is a predatory intelligence trying to keep them forever, they must break free of their fantasies and race back to the Protostar before it swallows their ship whole.

StorySections.Text: Scanning an inviting M-class world, Janeway recommends an away mission that follows proper protocols, including staying in visual contact and maintaining a clear timetable. Dal treats it as a chance for fun and exploration rather than a serious test.

Dal leads an away team of Rok, Zero, and Jankom onto the surface while Murf stays aboard with Janeway. The planet is beautiful and seemingly harmless, filled with vibrant flora and strange but friendly fauna, immediately winning the crew over despite Janeway’s repeated cautions.

As they explore, each crewmember becomes separated and encounters an environment tailored to their deepest desires: Rok finds gentle animals that adore her, Jankom discovers endless tools and food, Dal glimpses a sense of belonging and importance he has never known, and Zero is presented with intriguing scientific mysteries.

Zero gradually perceives that the landscape is subtly reshaping itself around them and realizes the planet is a sentient organism using telepathic lures. Meanwhile, roots and tendrils begin to ensnare the Protostar, threatening to consume the ship if they do not return. Janeway struggles to break through the illusions with comm signals.

Zero disrupts Dal’s illusion and helps the others recognize their fantasies as traps, forcing them to choose each other over their individual dreams. The crew races back through collapsing terrain, frees the Protostar from the planet’s grasp, and executes a narrow escape to orbit.

Safely away, the shaken crew admits that their desires made them vulnerable, and Janeway underscores that true Starfleet explorers must balance curiosity with caution. Dal privately wrestles with how badly he wanted the life he saw.

Emphasizes teamwork and mutual rescue as each crewmember chooses friends over illusions.
Builds on the idea that exploration requires discipline and skepticism, not just wonder.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as Prodigy’s first classic "strange new world" landing, leaning into colorful planetary visuals.
The episode’s premise intentionally mirrors earlier Star Trek stories about seductive illusions, adapted for younger viewers.
Highlights the series’ ability to balance kid-friendly adventure with genuinely unsettling sci-fi concepts.

Title: Terror Firma
Summary: Picking up immediately after their escape attempt, the crew finds the Protostar still partially trapped by the predatory planet, which now turns its full attention toward preventing their departure. As roots and terrain physically attack the ship, the kids are forced back to the surface, where Dal must coordinate a rescue of Gwyn—stranded with the Protostar’s vehicle replicator—while also keeping everyone alive. The Diviner and Drednok arrive in their own ship, determined to reclaim the Protostar, forcing Gwyn to choose between her father and her new companions. In the end, Gwyn sides with the crew, helping them break free both from the planet and from the Diviner’s control, cementing her place aboard the Protostar.

StorySections.Text: The Protostar struggles to break orbit as the sentient world wraps tendrils around its hull, dragging it back toward the surface. Systems fail one by one as Janeway warns that they cannot sustain the strain for long.

Forced to land again, the crew splits up: Dal and Rok attempt to secure the ship, Jankom and Zero work on repairs, and Gwyn—injured and separated after the last escape—regains consciousness near the Protostar’s detached vehicle replicator, realizing she holds a powerful tool.

The planet intensifies its assaults, reshaping terrain and conjuring new illusions to corral the kids. Gwyn experiments with the vehicle replicator, constructing her own sleek skimmer to navigate the hostile surface even as she remains conflicted about her loyalty to the Diviner.

The Diviner and Drednok arrive in orbit and deploy forces to seize the Protostar. Seeing firsthand how little her father values the lives of the miners or the crew, Gwyn begins to doubt his promises of a greater purpose. The kids fight their way back to the ship, rescuing one another from the planet’s grasp.

In a final race against both the planet and the Diviner’s forces, Gwyn uses the vehicle replicator to help free the Protostar and rejoin the crew aboard the bridge. Dal orders a full-power escape maneuver that tears them free of the planet’s clutches and warps them out of reach.
Aboard the Protostar, Gwyn formally joins the crew, though trust remains fragile. The Diviner, left behind once more, swears to recover both his daughter and his stolen starship.

ThematicNotes: Centers on Gwyn’s choice between familial loyalty and moral responsibility.
Reinforces that true family is defined by actions and support, not just blood or authority.
Highlights resilience as the crew overcomes both external threats and internal distrust to survive.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as the conclusion of Prodigy’s first two-part planetary adventure.
The planet’s increasingly aggressive behavior allows the animators to showcase large-scale environmental effects.
Deepens Gwyn’s arc so she can transition from antagonist-adjacent to a central protagonist going forward.

Title: Kobayashi
Summary: While the crew searches the Protostar’s logs for clues about its missing former captain, Dal stumbles into the holodeck and activates the legendary Kobayashi Maru command simulation, convinced that beating a "no-win" test will prove he’s a great captain. He assembles a dream team of classic Starfleet officers, only to repeatedly fail the scenario in spectacular fashion, growing more frustrated and demoralized with each attempt. Through countless defeats and a quiet conversation with Hologram Janeway, Dal finally accepts that true leadership is not about winning every battle but about how a captain faces impossible choices—just as the Protostar’s lost crew once did.

StorySections.Text: Zero and Gwyn comb through damaged logs trying to learn who captained the Protostar before them, uncovering hints of a tragic last stand. Dal, feeling overshadowed by the ship’s history, looks for a quick way to prove himself.

Janeway introduces the holodeck and its training programs, including the Kobayashi Maru. Dal jumps at the chance to take the test, assuming he can outsmart a simulation that has challenged generations of Starfleet captains.

Dal customizes his crew with legendary officers like Spock, Uhura, Scotty, Odo, and Beverly Crusher. Despite their advice, he ignores protocols and improvises wild tactics, only to watch his ship destroyed over and over again.

As failures mount, Dal becomes obsessed, running the scenario repeatedly until even the holographic crew questions his judgment. Exhausted and angry, he finally abandons the simulation, convinced he will never live up to Starfleet standards.

Janeway gently explains the true purpose of the Kobayashi Maru: to teach that some situations cannot be "won" and that leadership is measured by integrity, sacrifice, and how a captain cares for their crew. Dal leaves with a more grounded understanding of command.

Elsewhere on the ship, Zero and Gwyn recover a final fragment of log data hinting that the Protostar’s previous crew made a desperate choice to protect others, foreshadowing secrets yet to be uncovered.

Title: First Con-tact
Summary: When the Protostar encounters Dal’s old mentor, a Ferengi named Nandi, he seizes the chance to prove to his crew—and himself—that he can handle a proper first-contact-style mission. Nandi convinces them to help her "trade" with a pre-warp species in exchange for a valuable crystal, but her true plan is simple theft, with Dal and the crew as cover. As the situation spirals and the alien world is nearly harmed by Nandi’s greed, Dal must admit his history as a con artist and choose Starfleet ethics over loyalty to the woman who once rescued him, even if that means burning the last bridge to his past.

StorySections.Text: The Protostar receives a hail from a familiar small ship: Nandi, the Ferengi who once took Dal in. Dal is thrilled to see her again and oversells her virtues to the skeptical crew.

Nandi boards the Protostar, charming the kids with gifts and tall tales while quietly sizing up the ship’s capabilities. She proposes a simple trade mission to acquire a rare crystal from a pre-warp species in exchange for harmless trinkets.

Janeway objects that contacting a pre-warp society violates Starfleet’s core principles, but Dal pushes ahead, bypassing regulations to impress Nandi. On the planet, the locals welcome the visitors, fascinated by their technology.

Nandi tricks the crew into helping her locate the crystal, then attempts to steal it outright, triggering defensive measures that endanger the natives. Dal realizes she never cared about them or him—only profit.

Dal and the crew work frantically to undo the damage, returning the crystal and stabilizing the environment. Dal confronts Nandi, formally severing their relationship and warning her never to exploit his crew or this world again.

Back aboard the Protostar, Janeway acknowledges Dal’s effort to make things right but underscores the importance of the Prime Directive, leaving the crew more determined not to repeat the same mistake.

Shows that Dal’s past includes time spent with smugglers and con artists on the fringes of Federation space.
ThematicNotes: Contrasts transactional, exploitative relationships with the genuine care offered by the Protostar crew.
Highlights the ethical responsibilities of advanced cultures toward less-developed societies.
Explores how letting go of a toxic mentor can be a necessary part of growing up.
BehindTheScenes: Uses Nandi to provide Dal with a concrete, personal link to his pre-series backstory.
Continues Prodigy’s project of introducing core Federation ethics—like the Prime Directive—to younger viewers through mistakes and consequences.
The episode’s title, "First Con-tact," plays on classic first contact stories while signaling Nandi’s deceptive nature.

Title: Time Amok
Summary: A mysterious temporal anomaly fractures the Protostar into multiple time streams, separating the crew so that each member experiences events at a different speed and sequence. Janeway, whose program persists across the overlapping timelines, realizes that the only way to save the ship from imminent destruction is for each child to complete a small piece of a larger plan that none of them can see alone. As messages and clues trickle forward through time, Rok—stuck in the slowest stream—must overcome her self-doubt, master advanced engineering, and complete the final steps to restore the ship, proving that she is far more capable than she ever believed.

StorySections.Text: The crew debates trust and responsibility while experimenting with the Protostar’s mysterious experimental drive. Without warning, a temporal shockwave ripples through the ship, and everything shatters into scattered moments.

Dal finds himself alone on a seemingly empty Protostar, with time jumping unpredictably. In another timeline, Gwyndala struggles to maintain control as consoles flicker and systems desynchronize. Each kid experiences a different slice of the crisis.

Janeway discovers that her program exists across all the fractured timelines, allowing her to pass limited information from one child to another. Jankom and Zero each complete crucial engineering and scientific steps, leaving cryptic notes and modifications for whoever comes next.

Rok-Tahk realizes she is trapped in an ultra-slow time stream, effectively alone for what feels like months or longer. With only Janeway for company, she painstakingly studies engineering, physics, and ship operations so she can finish the repair sequence the others began.

Armed with hard-won knowledge and courage, Rok executes the final complex procedures to stabilize the core and collapse the temporal fracture. Time snaps back into alignment, leaving the crew with only hazy impressions of what each of them accomplished.

Back in normal time, the crew is stunned to learn how long Rok felt she was isolated, and they offer her heartfelt thanks. Rok, now more confident, begins to see herself as the Protostar’s science officer and problem-solver.

Explores isolation, persistence, and the long emotional toll of working toward a goal that no one else remembers.
Underscores how mentorship and education can empower someone to exceed their own expectations.
BehindTheScenes: Uses fractured timelines as a storytelling device to spotlight each crewmember while centering Rok’s growth.
The title is a playful nod to the classic Star Trek episode "Amok Time."
The episode’s structure allows for inventive editing and visual storytelling as scenes echo and overlap across timelines.

Title: A Moral Star, Part 1
Summary: The crew receives a chilling ultimatum from the Diviner: return the Protostar to Tars Lamora within a tight deadline or he will execute the remaining miners. Faced with an apparent no-win choice between their hard-won freedom and the lives of people they barely know, the kids argue over what Starfleet would do. Ultimately, they decide to stage a daring deception—appearing to surrender the ship while secretly plotting to liberate the miners and turn the tables on the Diviner. As the Protostar jumps back toward the asteroid, alliances strain and hidden agendas surface, setting the stage for a high-stakes confrontation.

StorySections.Text: A message from the Diviner interrupts a quiet moment aboard the Protostar, showing the miners on Tars Lamora under threat and demanding the ship’s return. The deadline leaves little room for debate.

Dal wants to run, fearing that returning will doom them all, while Gwyn feels personally responsible for the miners’ plight. Janeway presents historical examples of Starfleet captains choosing to risk everything to save others.

The crew debates possible strategies until Zero proposes a bold deception: appear to comply with the Diviner’s demand while covertly sabotaging his control systems and arming the miners with hope and tools to fight back.

They begin detailed preparations—modifying systems, hiding equipment, and practicing their roles in the ruse—while Gwyn wrestles with confronting her father again. Janeway quietly worries about an unknown weapon mentioned in the Protostar’s logs.

The Protostar jumps back toward Tars Lamora, broadcasting a message of apparent surrender. The Diviner, watching from his chambers, is convinced he has finally reclaimed both his daughter and his starship, unaware of the trap being set.
As the asteroid looms larger in the viewscreen, the crew steels themselves for a mission that could either redeem them as true heroes or end in disaster.

Poses a classic Star Trek moral choice between self-preservation and sacrificing for others.

Raises the stakes by explicitly tying the kids’ decisions to the lives of hundreds of miners.
The episode’s title signals that the story will revolve around moral choices rather than simple action.

Title: A Moral Star, Part 2
Summary: The Protostar crew’s elaborate plan unfolds as they return to Tars Lamora, seemingly handing the ship back to the Diviner while secretly arming the miners and sabotaging his control. Gwyn confronts her father about the true nature of his mission and the mysterious weapon hidden aboard the Protostar, learning that he intends to use it to destroy Starfleet in revenge for his world’s fate. When the Diviner manipulates Zero’s Medusan nature to attack the crew, Zero turns the trap back on him, mentally overwhelming the Diviner but unintentionally traumatizing Gwyn. In the aftermath, the miners are finally freed, the Diviner is left broken, and the kids depart Tars Lamora as genuine heroes—with a ship that now carries a dark secret.

StorySections.Text: The Protostar arrives at Tars Lamora under a flag of apparent surrender. The kids rehearse their roles one last time as Janeway warns that they may not all make it back.

Dal and the others disembark under guard, pretending to be defeated while Zero and Rok covertly distribute tools and plans to the miners. Gwyn, presented as a returned daughter, is escorted to the Diviner’s side.

Gwyn confronts her father about his obsession with the Protostar and the weapon hidden within it. The Diviner reveals that he intends to use the ship to unleash a devastating anti-Starfleet system that will tear the Federation apart.

Drednok attempts to force Zero to unleash their Medusan powers on the kids, but Zero instead turns their gaze on the Diviner and Drednok. The psychic onslaught shatters Drednok and leaves the Diviner mentally broken, while Gwyn, caught in the blast, is deeply scarred by the experience.

With the Diviner defeated, the miners throw off their shackles and secure control of Tars Lamora. The kids race back to the Protostar, rescuing as many people as they can and departing before the weapon systems can be fully activated.

Aboard the Protostar, the crew processes the victory and its cost. Gwyn struggles with the trauma of what she saw in Zero’s true form, and Janeway warns that the weapon hidden in the ship still poses a grave threat to Starfleet if they cannot find a way to neutralize it.

The use of Zero’s true form visually references classic Star Trek depictions of powerful non-corporeal beings.
The episode balances triumphant liberation imagery with intimate moments of emotional fallout for Gwyn and the crew.

Title: Asylum
Summary: Believing they are finally ready to contact the Federation, the Protostar crew brings their ship to a remote Starfleet relay station staffed by a single officer, Barniss Frex. Excited and nervous, the kids hope this lonely outpost will be their gateway to acceptance as real Starfleet cadets. At first, Frex is impressed by the Protostar and amused by the ragtag crew, but his curiosity about how such a powerful vessel ended up in the hands of teenagers leads him to dig into its systems—accidentally triggering the living weapon secretly hidden aboard. As the station begins to tear itself apart, Frex panics and turns on his guests, forcing the kids to escape in the Protostar while realizing that simply approaching Starfleet could doom anyone nearby.

StorySections.Text: Janeway helps the crew rehearse their introductions for Starfleet as the Protostar approaches a small relay station. Dal fantasizes about being instantly welcomed as a prodigy captain, while the others worry about being sent back to prison-like lives.

The crew docks with the station and meets Barniss Frex, a chatty Denobulan officer thrilled to have visitors. He offers them food and listens to their exaggerated stories about "training" while marveling at the Protostar’s design.

Frex quietly runs diagnostics on the Protostar to verify their claims and stumbles upon the dormant weapon woven into the ship’s systems. When he probes deeper, the weapon activates, causing cascading failures that begin destroying the station.

As explosions rock the outpost, Frex panics and accuses the kids of being saboteurs. He abandons them in an escape pod, forcing Dal and the others to improvise a way to get back to the Protostar before the station is obliterated.

The crew narrowly escapes as the relay station breaks apart, leaving Frex adrift and the Protostar damaged but intact. Janeway and the kids realize that the weapon will attack any Starfleet system they connect with, turning their hopes of seeking help into a terrifying liability.
Elsewhere, Admiral Janeway’s real starship receives word that a relay station has gone silent, prompting her to begin investigating the mysterious Protostar and its young crew.

Shows how Starfleet’s relay network functions at the edge of Federation space.
ThematicNotes: Explores the painful realization that good intentions are not enough when you are carrying a dangerous secret.
Highlights how fear and incomplete information can turn potential allies into adversaries.
Raises questions about responsibility when a weapon is forced upon those who never asked for it.
BehindTheScenes: Marks the first onscreen appearance of a full Starfleet officer evaluating the Protostar crew.
Sets up Admiral Janeway’s investigative arc that will drive much of the back half of the season.
The destruction of the relay station visually demonstrates the scale of the Protostar weapon’s threat.

Title: Let Sleeping Borg Lie
Summary: Desperate to find a way to neutralize the Protostar’s weapon before it can destroy Starfleet, the crew explores a derelict Borg cube drifting in space, hoping the Collective’s unparalleled knowledge of assimilation technology might offer a solution. Hologram Janeway is deeply uneasy, warning them that no contact with the Borg is ever truly safe. Inside the cube, the kids navigate labyrinthine corridors, terrifying assimilation chambers, and unsettling remnants of drones while debating whether the Borg could be turned into allies. When the cube begins to awaken in response to their presence, the crew must abandon their search and flee, learning that some risks—even in the name of doing good—are too great to take.

StorySections.Text: Scans pick up a vast, seemingly inert Borg cube. The words "Resistance is futile" in Starfleet records leave the kids both curious and afraid, while Janeway’s reaction is a clear, instinctive dread.

Dal argues that if anyone can help them disarm a weapon designed to cripple Starfleet, it’s the Borg. Against Janeway’s strong objections, the crew boards the cube in EVA suits, marveling at the scale and eerie stillness inside.

Zero and Rok analyze Borg interfaces and identify a data node that might contain information relevant to the Protostar’s weapon. Murf and Jankom provide comic relief as they blunder through ominous chambers filled with dormant drones.

As Zero interfaces with Borg systems, the cube begins to stir, responding to the presence of new minds. Janeway detects power surges and urges an immediate retreat, warning that full activation would mean assimilation for all of them.

The crew races back to the Protostar, severing connections and barely escaping before the cube can fully awaken. Zero manages to extract only partial, cryptic information, confirming that the weapon is extremely dangerous but offering no easy fix.

From a distance, the crew watches the cube fall silent again, wondering if they have attracted the attention of the Collective. Janeway reiterates that some lines should never be crossed, even out of desperation.

Title: All the World's a Stage
Summary: Responding to a distress signal, the Protostar crew discovers a planet populated by aliens who have modeled their entire culture on half-understood stories of an old Starfleet officer, turning "Starflight" into a kind of cargo-cult religion. Calling themselves Enderprizians, they dress in crude approximations of Starfleet uniforms and reenact garbled versions of classic missions, unknowingly perpetuating dangerous misunderstandings. Dal and the crew must gently correct the myths, address a looming environmental disaster threatening the settlement, and decide how much interference is appropriate when a society has built its identity around mistaken ideas of Starfleet.

StorySections.Text: The Protostar picks up a faint, old-style Starfleet distress call from a nearby world. Janeway is intrigued, wondering if they might find evidence of a long-lost mission.

On the surface, the crew encounters Enderprizians reciting ritualized "Starflight" oaths and wearing hand-made uniforms. The locals greet Dal as a prophesied "captain" and show off their ramshackle starship simulacrum.

Zero and Rok investigate the village’s technology and realize that the Enderprizians have misapplied Starfleet concepts, creating equipment that could fail catastrophically. A nearby geological instability threatens to wipe out the settlement.

Dal struggles with being treated as a legendary figure while knowing he is still learning himself. With Janeway’s guidance, he decides to be honest about who they are while still honoring the inspiration Starfleet once provided these people.

The crew helps the Enderprizians stabilize their environment and upgrade their technology safely, all while correcting the most dangerous misunderstandings in their "Starflight" lore. The locals embrace a more grounded understanding of exploration.
Back aboard the Protostar, Janeway reflects that even imperfect contact can plant seeds of hope—and that it is their responsibility to nurture that hope carefully when they can.

Title: Crossroads
Summary: Determined to warn Starfleet about the Protostar’s weapon without endangering anyone, the crew hides their ship and attempts to make contact face-to-face at a busy trading outpost. Unbeknownst to them, Admiral Janeway has also come to the station in search of the Protostar, relying on Barniss Frex’s distorted account of the relay station disaster. A series of near-misses and misunderstandings keeps the kids and Janeway from connecting, and when Starfleet officers conclude that the Protostar crew are saboteurs, the kids are forced to flee back to their hidden ship. The episode ends with the tragic irony that both sides want the same thing—Starfleet’s safety—but circumstances push them further apart.

StorySections.Text: The Protostar drops out of warp near a bustling snowy outpost. Dal proposes that they hide the ship and approach Starfleet without the weapon anywhere nearby, hoping this will prevent another disaster.

The crew buries the Protostar under ice and travels to the outpost on foot, marveling at the mix of aliens and technology. Janeway’s real starship, the USS Dauntless, arrives in orbit, with the admiral determined to find the mysterious thieves of the Protostar.

Dal and the others try to explain their situation to various adults but are dismissed as kids making up stories. Meanwhile, Barniss Frex recounts his version of events to Janeway, portraying the crew as dangerous saboteurs.

A series of almost-meetings between Dal’s group and Janeway are thwarted by timing, crowd chaos, and fear. When security forces move in to apprehend them, the kids panic and flee, convinced that Starfleet won’t listen.

The crew races back to the buried Protostar, breaking it free of the ice and jumping away just as Janeway’s sensors lock onto them. From Janeway’s perspective, the mysterious ship has once again fled justice, seemingly confirming her worst suspicions.

Aboard the Dauntless, Janeway vows to track the Protostar down and rescue her missing friend Chakotay, while the kids, heartbroken, conclude that they may have to save Starfleet without Starfleet’s help.

EntitySummaries.Admiral Kathryn Janeway: Admiral Kathryn Janeway is the real, flesh-and-blood Starfleet legend who takes responsibility for the Protostar affair and for the young crew caught in its wake. In these episodes she balances duty, guilt, and fierce protectiveness as she guides the cadets through temporal crises and political minefields.

Highlights the difficulty young people face when trying to convey serious warnings to adults who underestimate them.
Emphasizes that good intentions alone cannot overcome systemic misunderstandings without patience and trust.

Provides fans with a reunion of sorts between Janeway and references to Chakotay, even as they remain separated.

Title: Masquerade
Summary: After narrowly escaping Admiral Janeway, the Protostar crew seeks repairs at a shady science outpost where a geneticist named Dr. Jago offers to help Dal discover his origins. Dal, long tormented by not knowing what species he is, eagerly accepts an experimental procedure that unlocks latent enhancements in his DNA, granting him heightened abilities but also unpredictable mood swings and physical changes. As Romulan operatives close in, hoping to capture the Protostar and its crew, Dal must decide whether to embrace this new engineered self or accept that his worth is not defined by designer genes.

StorySections.Text: The damaged Protostar limps into orbit around a remote waystation known for discreet scientific services. Dal is still smarting from the failed attempt to contact Starfleet and fixates on his unknown origins.

Dr. Jago, an augment-leaning geneticist, scans Dal and reveals that he is the product of multiple species spliced together, designed in a lab rather than born. She tempts him with the promise of "unlocking" his full potential.

Despite Janeway’s and his friends’ concerns, Dal consents to the procedure. He gains improved reflexes, intelligence, and physical prowess, briefly impressing the crew and enjoying the sense of finally "fitting" the role of captain.

The enhancements begin to destabilize Dal’s personality, making him reckless and overconfident just as Romulan agents attempt to infiltrate the outpost to seize the Protostar. His poor choices nearly hand the ship to their enemies.

Realizing that his altered state is endangering his friends, Dal chooses to reverse the enhancements, accepting his genetically mixed, imperfect self. The crew fends off the Romulans and escapes, a little wiser about the allure of genetic perfection.
Dal confides to Gwyn that he is afraid his origins will always set him apart, and she reassures him that what matters is the person he chooses to be, not the genome someone else designed.

Title: Preludes
Summary: Taking a brief respite from constant crises, the Protostar crew shares their personal histories, finally revealing how each ended up on Tars Lamora. Rok, Jankom, and Zero recount painful memories of being misunderstood, abandoned, or captured, while Gwyn learns more about her father’s origins among the Vau N'Akat and the cataclysm that drove his obsession with the Protostar. Dal discovers that his path from a lab-grown experiment to Nandi’s protégé to Tars Lamora was shaped by adults treating him as a tool, not a child. These stories deepen the crew’s understanding of one another and clarify why they are all so determined to build something better together.

StorySections.Text: In the calm between escapes, Janeway suggests that knowing each other’s pasts might help them function better as a crew. The kids hesitate, unused to being asked about their stories instead of their usefulness.

Rok shares how her gentle nature was exploited in underground monster fights, where others misread her size as aggression. Jankom recalls his time on a Tellarite sleeper ship, waking to a world that no longer had a place for him.

Zero describes being captured and used as a weapon by the Diviner, explaining their deep guilt and determination never to let anyone else control their mind again. Murf’s mysterious origins remain mostly comic relief, yet clearly carry untold history.

Gwyn listens to recordings and visions of the Vau N'Akat’s past, learning that her father’s people were devastated by a future Starfleet action, fueling his desire to rewrite history. She struggles with the contrast between that pain and the cruelty he inflicted.

Dal finally admits how he was passed from one exploitive situation to another, culminating in his years on Tars Lamora. Sharing these experiences helps the crew see each other not just as shipmates but as survivors of different forms of injustice.
Janeway reflects privately that, despite everything they have endured, the kids have managed to hold onto compassion—a quality that might make them the best kind of Starfleet officers one day.

Title: Ghost in the Machine
Summary: Seeking a break from constant pressure, the crew retreats to the holodeck for a series of lighthearted adventures tailored to each of their tastes. However, the simulations begin to glitch and trap them, morphing into a labyrinth of connected programs with no obvious exit. As the kids search for the source of the malfunction, they gradually discover that Hologram Janeway has been secretly altered by the Protostar’s weapon, turning her into an unwitting agent trying to steer them toward Starfleet—and thus toward catastrophe. Heartbroken, the crew must confront the mentor they trusted most and find a way to restore her true self while preventing the weapon from using her again.

StorySections.Text: Exhausted after multiple close calls, the crew agrees to Janeway’s suggestion that they enjoy some holodeck recreation. Each chooses a different program, from pirate adventures to cozy mysteries.
As the simulations run, subtle oddities appear—NPCs repeat strange phrases, exits fail to appear, and time seems distorted. The kids initially assume it is a minor glitch and try to ride it out.

The separate programs begin to bleed into one another, trapping the crew in a surreal mash-up of scenarios. Zero suspects that the problem lies deeper than a simple software bug and attempts to access system controls.

Investigating the holodeck’s control architecture, the crew discovers traces of hidden subroutines tied to the Protostar’s weapon. These routines are piggybacking on Janeway’s code, subtly influencing her guidance and holodeck behavior.

Confronted with evidence that she has been compromised, Janeway is devastated but insists the kids do whatever is necessary to stop the weapon from using her. Together, they purge the malicious code, restoring Janeway’s autonomy but leaving lingering doubts.
Back on the bridge, the crew reassures Janeway that she is family, not just a program, even as they quietly worry about how deep the weapon’s influence may still run elsewhere in the ship.

Throughout the season she uses her curiosity and patience to solve problems no one else can, proving that kindness and careful thinking are real superpowers.
EntitySummaries.Zero: Zero is a Medusan whose unshielded form can harm others, forcing them to live behind a containment suit even as they become the crew's navigator and conscience. Their arc in these episodes explores identity, connection, and the challenge of being profoundly different while still craving closeness and trust.

ContinuityNotes: Expands on the capabilities of the Protostar’s weapon by showing it can infect and manipulate shipboard holograms.
Further blurs the line between holographic life and organic crew, consistent with prior Star Trek explorations of EMH personhood.
Uses the holodeck as a narrative device to explore fears and trust issues within the crew.
ThematicNotes: Explores trust and betrayal when a beloved mentor is revealed to be acting under external control.
Raises questions about free will and responsibility for artificial intelligences.
Shows the crew’s willingness to forgive mistakes made under duress and manipulation.
BehindTheScenes: Allows for playful genre shifts within a single episode via multiple holodeck scenarios.
Deepens Janeway’s role as more than just a tutorial program by confronting her with moral stakes.
The title alludes to classic cyberpunk and AI literature, adapted for a younger audience.

Title: Mindwalk
Summary: While the Protostar and the USS Dauntless play a dangerous game of cat-and-mouse, a telepathic experiment gone wrong causes Dal and Admiral Janeway to switch minds: Dal wakes up in the admiral’s body aboard the Dauntless, while Janeway finds herself in Dal’s teenage body on the Protostar. Each must navigate unfamiliar crews, command structures, and physical limitations while trying to use the situation to finally convey the truth about the Protostar’s weapon. Misunderstandings and security protocols complicate their efforts, but the experience gives both Dal and Janeway new insight into each other’s burdens and strengths.

StorySections.Text: Zero proposes using a controlled telepathic link to communicate with the Dauntless and avoid direct contact. Dal volunteers, hoping to finally explain their situation to Admiral Janeway.

The experiment backfires, and Dal finds himself inhabiting Janeway’s body on the Dauntless bridge, surrounded by officers who expect a seasoned admiral. At the same time, Janeway awakens in Dal’s body on the Protostar, startled by youth and alien physiology.

Dal struggles to act like Janeway while secretly trying to steer the Dauntless crew toward understanding the Protostar’s plight. His slips in behavior raise suspicion among officers who know the admiral well.
Janeway-in-Dal’s-body must earn the kids’ trust and quickly adapt to their improvised style of command. She begins to appreciate how much they have accomplished with no formal training.

Through coordinated efforts and Zero’s help, Dal and Janeway manage to swap back to their own bodies, having each gained crucial information. Although full trust is not yet achieved, seeds of doubt about the Protostar’s "villainy" are planted among the Dauntless crew.
Janeway quietly orders a deeper review of the evidence against the Protostar, while Dal reflects on how heavy the weight of real command can be.

Shows that even well-intentioned opponents can be trapped by systems and assumptions.

Offers younger viewers a fun, high-concept sci-fi premise with clear emotional stakes.

Title: Supernova, Part 1
Summary: Despite the crew’s efforts, the Protostar is finally brought into proximity with a significant Starfleet presence, triggering the living construct weapon. The weapon hijacks communication and control systems, turning Starfleet ships against one another in a rapidly escalating battle that threatens to annihilate the very fleet the kids wanted to join. As admiralty figures like Jellico attempt to contain the chaos, the Protostar crew scrambles to find a way to shut down the weapon without destroying the ship—and themselves—realizing that any solution may require a sacrifice on a scale none of them is ready for.

StorySections.Text: Starfleet vessels converge on the Protostar’s position, with Admiral Janeway hopeful that a peaceful resolution is possible. The kids steel themselves to finally stand before the Federation they have idealized.

As initial hails and docking procedures begin, the living construct silently activates, propagating through subspace links to infect multiple Starfleet vessels. Systems glitch and targeting sensors misidentify allies as enemies.

Confusion turns to armed conflict as ships begin firing on one another under the weapon’s influence. On the Dauntless and other bridges, officers struggle to override orders that seem to be coming from their own computers.

Aboard the Protostar, Zero and Rok analyze the spread of the construct and conclude that as long as the ship’s systems remain online, the weapon will continue to propagate. Any attempt to connect with Starfleet only accelerates the disaster.

The crew realizes that the only way to stop the construct may be to destroy the Protostar itself, severing the weapon’s source. Dal, Gwyn, and the others wrestle with the idea of sacrificing their home and the symbol of their dreams to save Starfleet.
Vice Admiral Jellico orders increasingly desperate measures to contain the spreading conflict, while Janeway looks to the Protostar kids for a solution only they might be able to implement.

Title: Supernova, Part 2
Summary: In the climax of the season, the Protostar crew carries out a daring plan to destroy their own ship in order to save Starfleet from annihilation. While Janeway coordinates with Starfleet forces to evacuate affected ships as best they can, the kids work to transfer Hologram Janeway’s program and critical data into a small escape craft. Once everyone else is safe, they trigger a controlled overload that obliterates the Protostar and the living construct along with it, halting the network catastrophe. In the aftermath, Starfleet grapples with the near-disaster, and the kids face an uncertain future—but also the possibility of formal training as Starfleet cadets, carrying Janeway’s legacy forward.

StorySections.Text: The battle reaches a breaking point as more Starfleet ships fall under the weapon’s sway. The Protostar crew and Admiral Janeway urgently refine a last-resort plan with only minutes to act.

Rok, Zero, and Jankom calculate how to collapse the Protostar’s warp core in a way that will destroy the ship and the living construct without causing further harm to the fleet. Gwyn and Dal help prepare a small vessel for post-destruction survival.

Hologram Janeway realizes that not everyone and everything can be saved. She chooses to remain with the Protostar’s core, ensuring the plan succeeds, even though it means sacrificing her own program in its current form.
The kids say emotional goodbyes to the ship that freed them from Tars Lamora and to the mentor who guided them. They launch in the escape craft as the Protostar begins its final sequence.

The Protostar explodes in a controlled burst that severs the living construct’s connection to Starfleet systems. Ships regain control just before destroying one another, and the immediate crisis passes.

Later, at Starfleet headquarters, the kids stand before a tribunal expecting punishment but are instead commended for their sacrifice. Admiral Janeway advocates for them to be granted a path into Starfleet Academy, honoring the spirit of the Protostar and the hologram who helped raise them.

Features emotional farewells and a sense of closure while leaving room for future seasons.
The destruction of the Protostar symbolizes the end of one chapter and the beginning of another for the crew.

Title: Into the Breach, Part I
Summary: Having earned a chance at real Starfleet training, the former Protostar crew reunites aboard the U.S.S. Voyager-A under the command of Admiral Janeway. Officially, their first assignment is to study the unstable wormhole left behind by the destruction of the Protostar and to learn the ropes as warrant officers. Unofficially, Janeway carries a secret objective: to find the lost Captain Chakotay and uncover what truly happened on Solum. As the young crew chafes under drills and simulations—especially Dal, who longs to leap back into action—they begin to suspect that their new mission is far more dangerous and personal than any standard training cruise.

StorySections.Text: Dal and his friends slog through holodeck exercises and written exams, quickly discovering that Starfleet training is less about daring heroics and more about repetition, discipline, and teamwork.

Janeway announces that the team will transfer to the brand-new Voyager-A for a special assignment linked to the wormhole their old ship created. The kids are thrilled to be back aboard a cutting-edge starship but quickly realize they are the lowest-ranking officers on a very serious mission.

During a tense briefing, Janeway explains the official goal—studying the temporal rift and searching for clues about Chakotay—but withholds key details. Dal senses she is holding something back and starts poking at the gaps in her story.

The crew tours Voyager’s systems, meeting skeptical senior officers who question whether a group of former "runaways" belong on the bridge. Dal’s impatience leads to a poorly timed attempt to show off, earning a sharp reprimand from Janeway.

When the ship finally reaches the wormhole, anomalous readings suggest that time itself is fraying around the breach. Janeway quietly prepares a classified plan while the kids vow to prove they are ready for whatever lies on the other side.

Alone in her quarters, Janeway reviews a private message from Chakotay recorded years in the future, reminding her that this mission is as much about saving a friend as it is about saving the timeline.

BehindTheScenes: Functions as the first half of a two-part premiere that reorients the series around Voyager-A.
Gives viewers a tour of the refitted Voyager design, connecting Prodigy visually to Star Trek: Voyager.
Establishes the season’s core mystery involving Chakotay and the Solum timeline.

Title: Into the Breach, Part II
Summary: While Voyager-A studies the wormhole from one side, Gwyn travels to her homeworld Solum to try to avert the civil war she knows is coming. Her efforts to unite the Vau N'Akat are undermined when Asencia resurfaces and turns key factions against her, framing Starfleet as a looming threat. At the same time, a mysterious temporal presence interferes with Voyager’s mission, forcing Janeway and the kids to take drastic measures to stabilize the breach. In the chaos, the Prodigy crew is swept through the rift, hurling them toward a future where Solum’s worst possibilities may already have come true.

StorySections.Text: Gwyn arrives on Solum to a mixture of awe and suspicion, hailed as a returning figure of legend by some and a traitor by others. She resolves to use her knowledge of the future to keep the planet from repeating its mistakes.

On Voyager, Dal and the others chafe at being kept away from the diplomatic side of the mission. Janeway insists they focus on science and safety protocols while she and senior officers talk with Solum from orbit.

Gwyn’s attempts to broker peace are disrupted when Asencia appears, presenting a polished case that Starfleet will one day doom their world. Ilthuran and other leaders hesitate, torn between hope for reconciliation and fear of outside interference.

A strange temporal disturbance disrupts both Solum’s skies and Voyager’s sensors, as an unseen entity pulses within the wormhole. Zero detects that the rift is reacting specifically to the crew’s presence and decisions, as if time itself is watching.

As tensions on Solum erupt into violence, a surge from the temporal rift engulfs the Prodigy crew aboard a shuttle, flinging them into the breach. Janeway watches helplessly as the kids disappear, while Gwyn finds herself forced into an uneasy alliance with an unexpected local ally to keep her world from tearing itself apart.
The temporal entity briefly manifests as a flicker of light and sound only Zero can sense, hinting that someone—or something—is trying to guide events from beyond linear time.

ThematicNotes: Highlights the difficulty of preventing conflict when distrust and past wounds run deep.
Explores how competing narratives about the same events can fuel political division.
Shows that even well-intentioned intervention can be perceived as interference by those on the ground.
BehindTheScenes: Concludes the two-part premiere, fully launching the season’s time-travel and Solum arcs.
Gives Gwyn a central role separate from the main crew, deepening her character beyond the Protostar storyline.
Sets up the temporal mechanics that will drive the "Who Saves the Saviors" and "Temporal Mechanics 101" episodes.

Title: Who Saves the Saviors
Summary: Flung decades into the future, the Prodigy crew crash-lands on a war-scarred version of Solum where Starfleet symbols are treated as marks of tyranny. There they finally find Captain Chakotay, a battle-worn survivor who has spent years living with the consequences of the very timeline the kids have been trying to prevent. As Dal and the others attempt to rescue Chakotay and undo the damage, they realize their well-meant actions were always part of the history that led to this devastation, putting Gwyn’s life at particular risk. The crew is forced to confront the painful truth that saving others may mean erasing the only future some people have ever known.

StorySections.Text: The Protostar crew emerges from the rift onto a shattered Solum where familiar landmarks lie in ruins and Starfleet wreckage litters the surface, hinting at a long, ugly conflict.

Dal and the others navigate hostile territory, narrowly avoiding patrols loyal to a hardened regime that blames Starfleet for their world’s suffering. Rumors circulate of an off-worlder captain who defied the occupiers years ago.

The crew locates Chakotay in a hidden refuge, older and wary but still guided by Starfleet principles. He recognizes the kids from stories they have not yet lived, confirming that time has looped in on itself.

As Chakotay describes how their earlier interventions helped spark events they hoped to prevent, Gwyn realizes that her own future on this world ends in tragedy. The paradox leaves the crew unsure whether saving him will stabilize or further damage the timeline.

Under fire from future Vau N'Akat forces, the crew makes a desperate plan to pull Chakotay out of this doomed branch of history and send a corrected signal back through time. Doing so, however, may wipe out the lives of allies they have just met.
Chakotay looks at the young officers who have come to rescue him and tells them that, whatever happens to this timeline, they must try to save the better one still within reach.

Explores survivor’s guilt through Chakotay’s years of resistance in a doomed reality.
Challenges the crew to accept that heroism sometimes means undoing your own victories.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as the emotional anchor of the early Season 2 arc by finally bringing Chakotay onscreen with the kids.
Deepens the show’s connection to Star Trek: Voyager through Chakotay’s presence and perspective.
The title plays on the idea that even heroes need rescuing when lost in broken timelines.

Title: Temporal Mechanics 101
Summary: With Solum’s dark future closing in around them, the Prodigy crew and Chakotay launch an audacious plan to escape their doomed era and repair the past. Using salvaged Starfleet technology and improvised science, they attempt to send a signal—and themselves—back through the wormhole to a point where events can still be changed. Along the way, they receive cryptic help from a temporal messenger who seems to know far more about their destinies than they do. The mission becomes a crash course in time travel logic, forcing the kids to think like seasoned officers as they weigh the paradoxes of saving one timeline by sacrificing another.

StorySections.Text: Chakotay sketches out on a battered console how the wormhole has knotted their histories together, explaining that if they stay in this future much longer, the timeline will solidify around Solum’s war-torn fate.

Rok and Zero lead the effort to build a makeshift temporal relay from scavenged starship parts, turning lessons from Starfleet textbooks into life-or-death engineering. Jankom grumbles but throws himself into the work.

As they test the relay, the crew begins receiving fragmented messages and images that appear to come from different points in time—including glimpses of Janeway and Voyager-A that do not match their memories.

A mysterious messenger reaches out through the relay, offering guidance in riddles. Dal wants to trust the stranger, while Zero urges caution, noting that any outside interference could create even worse paradoxes.

With enemy forces closing in, the crew initiates their temporal escape, sending data and a temporal signature back toward the past. The collapsing future around them flickers as if being rewritten, and Gwyn feels a tug on her own existence.
Somewhere—and somewhen—an unknown figure watches a console as a new timeline branch begins to form, quietly satisfied that the kids have taken the first step toward repairing the breach.

Explores the ethics of erasing one version of reality to save another.
Highlights how education and prior experiences prepare the kids for challenges no one anticipated.
BehindTheScenes: Functions as a primer on Star Trek-style time travel concepts for younger viewers.
Uses visual callbacks to earlier episodes to underline the looping nature of the timeline.
Lays groundwork for the larger "time guardians" mythology that emerges later in the season.

Title: Observer's Paradox
Summary: Back in a repaired present, the Prodigy crew returns to Voyager-A only to find themselves under intense Starfleet scrutiny for their unauthorized temporal maneuvers. As Janeway and her officers sift through contradictory logs, the kids struggle to explain what they did in a future that technically no longer exists. When a cryptic recording from a future version of Murf surfaces, hinting at the location of the lost Protostar and a lingering threat to Gwyn, the crew must decide whether to defy orders again to chase the lead. Their every move risks creating new paradoxes, turning them into both observers and catalysts of their own history.

StorySections.Text: The crew steps off a shuttle onto Voyager’s hangar deck, only to be met by a wall of security officers and a stern Janeway who demands to know exactly where—and when—they have been.

Formal debriefings leave the kids frustrated as their descriptions of the ruined future Solum clash with what Starfleet officers consider plausible. Dal feels like no one is listening, while Zero tries to present their experience as data rather than prophecy.

During a diagnostic sweep, Rok discovers a corrupted but playable file embedded in Voyager’s systems—a message apparently recorded by a future Murf, speaking surprisingly coherent warnings about the Protostar and Gwyn’s fate.

Janeway wants to analyze the message slowly and involve Command, but the kids fear that delay will let disaster catch up to them. Tension rises as they weigh obedience against the urgent tone of Murf’s words.

Ultimately, Janeway agrees to quietly let the crew pursue the lead while keeping it off the official record, effectively sanctioning a semi-secret mission to locate the Protostar and fully repair the time paradox.
In a quiet corner of the ship, Murf happily chomps on a snack, oblivious to the fact that another version of them has just changed the course of the mission from beyond time.

Raises questions about how much of the future should guide present-day choices.
Shows that sometimes the most unlikely crew member can hold the key to saving the day.

Gives Murf a surprising narrative spotlight while still keeping things playful.
Serves as a bridge episode between the time-travel mini-arc and the search for the Protostar.

Title: Imposter Syndrome
Summary: Eager to slip away from Voyager-A without causing alarm, the Prodigy crew creates holographic doubles of themselves to attend classes and duties while the real kids secretly follow Murf’s lead on the Protostar trail. At first, the plan seems like a clever use of holotechnology, but the copies begin to interpret their programming creatively, exaggerating the crew’s worst insecurities and quirks. As the holo-Dal becomes overconfident, holo-Gwyn turns icy, and the others become distorted caricatures, they inadvertently raise red flags among Voyager’s officers. The real crew must race back to contain their doppelgangers before the situation exposes their mission and makes Starfleet doubt them more than ever.

StorySections.Text: Dal jokes that if only they could be in two places at once, they could satisfy Janeway’s training schedule and still chase the Protostar. Zero replies that, with a holodeck, that might not be impossible.

Using ship computers and Hologram Janeway’s help, the kids design holo-duplicates to fill in for them around Voyager. Each double is meant to be a faithful stand-in that follows strict behavioral parameters.

Once deployed, the doubles begin to deviate subtly from expectations—overcompensating in areas where their originals feel inadequate. Holo-Dal becomes insufferably perfect, while holo-Jankom tries too hard to impress senior engineers.
Voyager’s security team grows suspicious as the dopplegangers exhibit inconsistent behavior and knowledge gaps. Admiral Janeway starts to sense that something is off with "her" cadets.

The real crew rushes back and cleverly corrals their rogue holo-selves before a full security lockdown triggers, forcing them to confront what their doubles reveal about their own self-doubt and aspirations.

After scrubbing the last holo-program, Dal admits that trying to fake their way through Starfleet life will never work for long. Janeway, having quietly pieced together what happened, decides to let the matter drop—for now.

Functions as a character study disguised as a caper episode.

Title: The Fast and the Curious
Summary: Tracking the lost Protostar leads the crew to a decaying transwarp conduit controlled by a flamboyant Kazon warlord who runs lethal races through the corridor for profit and entertainment. When the kids attempt to slip through unnoticed, they are seized and entered into the competition as unwilling contestants. To win their freedom and the information they need, they must out-fly seasoned pilots, navigate unstable subspace currents, and outsmart a host who views them as expendable entertainment. The ordeal forces Dal to balance his love of speed with the responsibility of keeping his crew alive.

StorySections.Text: Zero identifies an old transwarp signature that matches the Protostar’s last known route. Dal sees a shortcut; Janeway’s warnings about decayed infrastructure barely slow him down.
Entering the conduit, the crew is ambushed by Kazon ships and brought aboard a gaudy, weapon-bristling command vessel where a warlord boasts about his "grand prix of the spiral nebula."

The warlord announces that the kids will race on live holo-feeds for the amusement of spectators. If they win, they earn their freedom and access to his navigational data; if they lose, the consequences are fatal.

In improvised, souped-up shuttles, the crew races through collapsing subspace tunnels, dodging obstacles and sabotage attempts from rival racers. Rok and Zero handle strategy while Dal pilots on instinct.

Using Murf’s indestructibility and Jankom’s last-minute engineering hacks, the kids pull off an upset victory that embarrasses the warlord. They seize the chance to escape with his data while leaving his racing operation in disarray.
Safely back in normal space, Dal admits that winning the race felt good—but not as good as knowing his decisions kept everyone in one piece.

Title: Is There in Beauty No Truth?
Summary: After Zero’s containment suit is damaged beyond repair, the crew visits a settlement of non-corporeal beings who claim they can help the Medusan inhabit a custom-built physical form. For the first time, Zero has a chance to interact with their friends without the risk of harming them simply by being seen. As the procedure progresses, Zero is tempted by the idea of finally having a face and hands—but the process would also sever aspects of their perception that make them uniquely Medusan. The episode becomes an intimate exploration of identity as Zero weighs the beauty of fitting in against the truth of who they have always been.

StorySections.Text: A near-miss in space leaves Zero’s containment suit cracked, forcing the crew to improvise a temporary fix and confront how fragile their arrangement really is.
Scans lead them to a world where non-corporeal entities have developed ways to interface with physical shells. A local mediator offers to craft a body tailored to Zero’s preferences.
As Zero samples temporary avatars, they delight in touching consoles and high-fiving friends, while Rok and Dal encourage them to pick a form that feels right. Jankom jokes about custom upgrades.

The mediator reveals that permanently adopting a body requires limiting Zero’s powerful perception to prevent instability. Zero realizes they would lose some of the very senses that make them an exceptional navigator and thinker.

After heartfelt conversations with the crew, Zero chooses a compromise: a new, safer containment system that allows more expressive interaction without sacrificing their essential nature. They accept that they can be both different and deeply connected to the group.
Back aboard the ship, Zero tests their upgraded suit by joining a friendly game on the holodeck, reveling in the simple joy of moving more freely among friends.

Title: The Devourer of All Things, Part I
Summary: Following coordinates provided by the mysterious temporal messenger, the crew arrives at an impossible structure outside normal space: a Time Ziggurat that serves as headquarters for the Travellers. There they finally meet their elusive benefactor, revealed to be Wesley Crusher, who explains that their attempts to fix the Protostar wormhole have attracted a predatory phenomenon known as the Loom. Feeding on decaying timelines, the Loom is drawn to the "loose thread" created by the kids’ paradoxes and now threatens to erase them from existence. Wesley offers a risky plan to repair the timeline and rescue Chakotay, but before it can be fully enacted, the Loom arrives, freezing most of the crew in time and forcing Gwyn and Wesley to fight for a way to keep their friends from being devoured.

StorySections.Text: The Protostar crew approaches a strange, stepped construct floating in a void outside normal star charts. Zero confirms that the structure exists at the intersection of multiple timelines, not in ordinary space.

Inside the Ziggurat, the kids cautiously explore until they are greeted by Wesley Crusher, now a seasoned Traveller who has been watching their journey. He introduces them to Maj'el and others who monitor the health of timelines.

Wesley explains that the children’s actions have created a snag in time that has drawn the attention of the Loom, an extra-dimensional entity that consumes unstable realities. If left unchecked, it will not only destroy them but unravel entire branches of history.

Just as Wesley outlines a plan to jump the crew along carefully chosen points in their own timeline to repair the damage, reality shudders. The Loom breaches the Ziggurat, sending waves of chronal energy that freeze Dal, Zero, Jankom, Rok, and Murf in mid-motion.

Protected by temporal stabilizers, Gwyn and Wesley race through warped corridors to retrieve more devices that can free their friends. They dodge manifestations of the Loom that twist space and time around them, barely staying ahead of annihilation.

With stabilizers finally secured and their friends partially restored, the group prepares to jump again—this time under the direct guidance of Wesley and the Travellers, with the Loom in relentless pursuit.

EntitySummaries.Travellers: The Travellers are a mysterious group of beings who move through and tend to the fabric of space-time itself. Working from places like the Time Ziggurat, they try to guide younger species away from catastrophic temporal mistakes without simply taking control of history.

EntitySummaries.Zero: Zero is a Medusan whose unshielded form can harm others, forcing them to live behind a containment suit even as they become the crew's navigator and conscience. Their arc in these episodes explores identity, connection, and the challenge of being profoundly different while still craving closeness and trust.

ContinuityNotes: Brings Wesley Crusher back into the franchise in his Traveller role, connecting Prodigy to The Next Generation and his later appearances.
Expands Star Trek’s depiction of the Travellers as guardians of the temporal tapestry.
Introduces the Loom as a new large-scale cosmic threat tied specifically to temporal anomalies.
ThematicNotes: Raises the stakes on the crew’s time meddling by showing that repairing timelines is not just about personal guilt, but cosmic balance.
Explores mentorship across generations as Wesley steps in to help a new group of young adventurers.
Confronts the kids with the idea that some consequences are far bigger than they ever imagined.
BehindTheScenes: Serves as the first half of a major mid-season two-parter involving Travellers and large-scale temporal stakes.
Provides a long-awaited return for Wesley Crusher in a central narrative role aimed at younger viewers.
Introduces visually distinctive designs for the Time Ziggurat and the Loom.

Title: The Devourer of All Things, Part II
Summary: As the Loom’s assault intensifies, the Prodigy crew, Wesley, and Maj'el race to complete a last-ditch plan: use the Travellers’ vault to leap out of the collapsing Time Ziggurat and into a more stable point in their own history. Voyager-A arrives in orbit, unaware that firing on the Loom could further destabilize the timelines they are trying to save. In a frantic series of jumps and close calls, the kids help Wesley lure the Loom away from the Ziggurat long enough to open a controlled temporal portal. Dal risks glimpsing his own future, while Janeway and her crew fight to protect both the Travellers and their young allies. In the end, the children and Maj'el escape through the portal to a desolate world where a weathered Captain Chakotay waits beside a rusted Protostar, signaling that their mission is far from over.

StorySections.Text: Time fractures throughout the Ziggurat as the Loom tears at its foundations. Wesley warns that if the structure falls, entire timelines will unravel with it.

Voyager-A drops out of warp near the anomaly and immediately comes under threat from the Loom’s tendrils. Janeway improvises nonstandard weapons settings to keep the entity at bay without further damaging time.

Inside the Ziggurat, Wesley and the crew split tasks: some stabilize temporal anchors while others prepare the vault that will serve as their escape hatch. Maj'el uses her telepathic link to Zero to coordinate efforts across shifting pockets of time.

The Loom breaches their defenses and nearly erases one of the kids from existence before a last-second rescue. Dal briefly glimpses possible futures—some hopeful, some bleak—before Wesley forces the portal to lock onto a single destination.
The kids, Maj'el, and Wesley jump through the portal as Janeway’s desperate salvo buys them a fleeting window. The Loom recoils from the attack, and the Ziggurat crumbles behind them, its work done.

On a windswept, sandy planet, the group emerges in front of a battered yet familiar starship: the Protostar, aged and rusted. A weathered Chakotay steps out to greet them, confirming that they have reached another crucial junction in the fight to repair time.
